Jepsen et al. studied LiAlH 4-LiNH 2 composites in several molar proportions [ 113]. The intermediary Li 4− x Al
x (NH) 2−2 x N 2 formed when the LiAlH 4-LiNH 2 ratio was 1:1.5, 1:2, and 1:2.5. This study supports that the LiNH 2 reacts with LiH to form Li 2NH and H 2. The main differences among the studies are mainly the molar proportions and milling conditions. This last parameter ranged from some minutes of manual milling in a mortar to several hours of mechanical milling. The use of additives, such as transition metal chlorides reduced, approximately 30 °C, the dehydrogenation temperature [ 114]. Regarding the reversibility, partial reversibility was proven while using rather hard conditions, i.e., 180 bar and 275 °C [ 111] or 100 bar and 425 °C [ 113]. However, the reversibility does not rely on the formation of LiAlH 4.
